title: Catalan Numbers - Part 4
course: Discrete Mathematics by Prof Sudarshan Iyengar

transcript.text: So we have seen that the total number of paths without crossing the diagonal from (0,0) to
any (n,n) is given by 2n choose n minus 2n choose n plus one.
This goes by the name the nth Catalan number denoted as Cn.
This was given by the mathematician Catalan.
So Cn is written as 2n choose n minus 2n choose n plus one.
After simplification we get it as one by n plus one into 2n choose n.
So let us see how the sequence Cn goes.
C1 is one by two into 2 choose 1 which is one.
C2 is one by three into 4 choose 2 which is 2.
C3 is one by four into 6 choose 3 which is 5 and C4 is one by five into 8 choose 4 which
So the Catalan numbers sequence is 1, 1, 2, 5, 14, 42, 132 and so on.
Let us see some interesting examples of Catalan numbers.
